content:
ASIA-PAC

Fonterra stated that total New Zealand dairy exports fell 3% during May. (Newswires)
 

UK

UK PM May is reportedly worried the "humble address" could be used to extend the Article 50 process and has warned senior Conservative lawmakers that the Labour party could use the old procedure to stop the UK leaving the EU without a deal if MPs vote to oppose her plans this Autumn. (FT)

UK PM May spokesman said technical notices during August and September will set out sensible precautions in the event of a no-deal Brexit and that this would also have consequences for the EU. (Newswires)

UK Brexit negotiators reportedly warned their EU counterparts that European-based investment funds that rely on British clients for their cash and profits could be hit by regulators unless the EU changes its stance regarding the UK’s financial services post-Brexit. (Guardian)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump, when asked if he would meet with Iran's Rouhani, said that he will meet with anybody and that there are no preconditions on any meeting with Iran. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said US will be observing IMF actions regarding Pakistan, while he added there is no reasoning for IMF tax dollars to be used in bailing out Chinese bond holders nor China itself. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump’s administration is reported to consider a unilateral tax cut of USD 100bln. (NYT)

US Commerce Secretary Ross said the right time to get aggressive on trade is when the economy is strong, while he added that they are closest to a trade deal on NAFTA especially with Mexico. In related news, US and Mexico plan to conduct ministerial-level NAFTA talks on Thursday in Washington according to Mexico government sources. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

ES futures were ticking up overnight, but ran out of steam beneath 2,822 before skidding to below 2,800 in afternoon trade. There doesn’t seem to be a specific catalyst for the downside, though some desks have now begun talking about the market reaching an ‘exhaustion point’ (Morgan Stanley’s equity strategists over the weekend), with a rotation from growth strategies to value strategies being seen. Ultimately, however, the ES has been going horizontally through most of July. The ES returned to the 2,800 level in late trade. Caterpillar (CAT) reported upbeat numbers, beating on the top- and bottom-lines, boosted its share buyback facility and its guidance, propelling the Dow Mini to pre-market highs. Harley Davidson (HOG) announced it would manufacture new lightweight motorbikes for Asian markets in the face of declining demand in the US. T-Mobile (TMUS) names Nokia as the company that would supply it with $3.5b;n next-generation 5G network equipment, making the world’s largest 5G deal so far, in a sign that the wireless upgrade cycle is taking shape. American Express (AXP) was slammed on reports it raised foreign exchange rates to clients without giving notice, which also heaped some pressure on Visa (V). After reports of sexual misconduct, CBS (CBS) said there had been no misconduct allegations nor settlements with CEO Moonves in his time at the company, though the company is probing allegations. In the energy sector, Chesapeake (CHK) plans to sell a stake in its Utica shale operations for $2bln, while KKR (KKR) and Williams Companies (WMB) formed a JV to purchase Discovery Midstream for $1.2bln. General Electric (GE) came off lows after WSJ reported that it is seeking a buyer for key parts of its digital business, citing sources. SPX -0.6% at 2803, NDX -1.4% at 7193, DJI -0.6% at 25308.

The Treasury curve steepened on Monday, though trade was thin ahead of this week’s central bank risk events (BOJ overnight, Fed Wednesday, BOE Thursday). Selling action today was being attributed to expectations that the BOJ would adjust its yield curve control parameters, with speculation that the BOJ might raise the target, or widen its tolerance band. Elsewhere, of note, the US Treasury sold 3-month paper at 2% on Monday, the highest since June 2008. Later, the US Treasury announced its quarterly financing estimates, where it estimates it will borrow $329bln in the Jul-Sep quarter (raising its estimate from $273bln), and estimates $769bln in net borrowing in H2 2018. US 10YR T-notes settled 2 ticks lower at 119-12.

US MARKET WRAP - 30 July 2018: Tech slides; Trump doubles-down on shutdown threat, says he is willing to negotiate with Iran
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities lower, Treasuries flat, crude up, dollar down.
* REAR-VIEW: Trump doubles-down on shutdown threat; Trump willing to negotiate with Iran; CAT beats, raises guidance.
* COMING-UP: BOJ; EZ CPI, GDP. CBT, China NBS PMIs, US PCE, API inventories.

* TRUMP WATCH: US President Donald Trump doubled-down on his threat to shut the government down at the end of September, if Democrats do not give him the votes for his border security agenda (which includes his border wall project). Trump on Monday said his demands were not ‘red lines’, however, and he always leaves room for negotiation. In other geopolitics, Trump said he was prepared to meet with Iran at any time, without preconditions, to thrash a new nuclear deal out.

* US PENDING HOME SALES: Gained 0.9% MM in June (Expected 0.0%) – the first increase since March – though was down 2.5% YY. “Sales continue to be hampered by the lack of homes for sale but the drag from low inventories may be fading,” Wells Fargo said, adding that the data bodes well for future existing homes sales data. Wells does note that low inventories and affordability issues remain a hurdle, however. June’s data did show inventories rising on a YY basis for the first time in three years, though they still remain at lean levels, particularly around the median selling price levels ($276.9k).

* SPX -0.6% at 2803, NDX -1.4% at 7193, DJI -0.6% at 25308. SECTORS: Energy: +0.9%, Materials: -0.2%, Industrials: -0.9%, Consumer Discretionary: -0.8%, Cons Staples: -0.1%, Health Care: +0.1%, Financials: 0.0%, Tech: -1.8%, Telecoms: +1.9%, Utilities: -0.6%.

* FUTURES: The ES was ticking up overnight, but ran out of steam beneath 2,822, then skidding to below 2,800 in afternoon trade. There doesn’t seem to be a specific catalyst for the downside, though some desks have now begun talking about the market reaching an ‘exhaustion point’ (Morgan Stanley’s equity strategists over the weekend), with a rotation from growth strategies to value strategies being seen. Ultimately, however, the ES has been going horizontally through most of July. The ES returned to the 2,800 level in late trade.

* EQUITY SPECIFICS: Caterpillar (CAT) reported upbeat numbers, beating on the top- and bottom-lines, boosted its share buyback facility and its guidance, propelling the Dow Mini to pre-market highs. Harley Davidson (HOG) announced it would manufacture new lightweight motorbikes for Asian markets in the face of declining demand in the US. T-Mobile (TMUS) names Nokia as the company that would supply it with $3.5b;n next-generation 5G network equipment, making the world’s largest 5G deal so far, in a sign that the wireless upgrade cycle is taking shape. American Express (AXP) was slammed on reports it raised foreign exchange rates to clients without giving notice, which also heaped some pressure on Visa (V). After reports of sexual misconduct, CBS (CBS) said there had been no misconduct allegations nor settlements with CEO Moonves in his time at the company, though the company is probing allegations. In the energy sector, Chesapeake (CHK) plans to sell a stake in its Utica shale operations for $2bln, while KKR (KKR) and Williams Companies (WMB) formed a JV to purchase Discovery Midstream for $1.2bln. General Electric (GE) came off lows after WSJ reported that it is seeking a buyer for key parts of its digital business, citing sources.

* WTI FUTURES (U8) SETTLES $1.44 HIGHER AT $70.13; BRENT (U8) SETTLES $0.68 HIGHER AT $74.97. WTI made its way above $70.00, though, with some desks suggesting technical factors were at play. “It calls fresh attention to the downtrend in US crude oil inventories and early estimates for a further draw of 3-4lmn bbls for the week,” Citi writes. “There is market talk of supply uncertainty supporting the rally, but we note Brent is lagging on today’s advance,” it added. Comments from Mexico’s president-elect from last week continued to be cited on Monday (Mexico will aim to boost crude production to 2.5mln BPD). The latest OPEC survey by Reuters finds Gulf members are set to lead the output boost in July, with declines being led by Iran, Angola and Libya; total July output is seen rising 70k BPD MM to 32.64mln BPD (including Congo, the newest member of the cartel), taking it to the highest levels since October 2017. Sources reported that supply of the five North Sea crude oil grades underpinning Brent are set to average 960K BPD in September (compared to 949K BPD in August). Elsewhere, strike action at Total’s UK North Sea oil platforms was underway on Monday.

* US 10YR T-NOTES SETTLE 2 TICKS LOWER AT 119-12. The Treasury curve steepened on Monday, though trade was thin ahead of this week’s central bank risk events (BOJ overnight, Fed Wednesday, BOE Thursday). Selling action today was being attributed to expectations that the BOJ would adjust its yield curve control parameters, with speculation that the BOJ might raise the target, or widen its tolerance band. Elsewhere, of note, the US Treasury sold 3-month paper at 2% on Monday, the highest since June 2008. Later, the US Treasury announced its quarterly financing estimates, where it estimates it will borrow $329bln in the Jul=Sep quarter (raising its estimate from $273bln), and estimates $769bln in net borrowing in H2 2018.

* DXY: The USD started the week off on a positive note, with yuan weakness being cited for the buck selling. However, gains were given up as European/US trade progressed. Bank month-end FX rebalancing models are giving strong dollar sell signals (though Barclays notes that the signal for USDJPY is weak). Analysts aren’t expecting much from the Fed that will change the dynamic of gradual hikes, and accordingly, are not expecting much action. Analysts were continuing to attribute USD weakness to the GDP data released on Friday, as well as positioning for other central bank activity this week (BOJ overnight, BOE Thursday, RBI, BCB, Banxico). Elsewhere, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin’s weekend comments where he expects US growth to hover around 3% for many years, has been questioned by analysts. Commerzbank said the view “appears unjustified, if not downright impossible,” noting the FX implications: “Because nonsensical growth expectations of the Secretary of the Treasury will lead to unsustainable fiscal policies and thus weigh on the USD, though it might not be seen immediately.

* GBP: Sterling is mixed (up against the buck, down against the euro). Twin forces are playing a role. On the one hand, the BOE is expected to lift rates by 25bps on Thursday, with attention on the statement and vote split. The consensus expects a dovish hike, which UBS says leaves some scope for disappointment from the market. There was also a round of negative Brexit news flow over the weekend, with the Times on Sunday reporting that the ECJ will likely have the final say in the arbitration of arguments over the practicalities of Brexit, including disputes over the divorce bill, and the Irish backstop. On Monday, the FT reported that UK Prime Minister May was warning Tory MPs that the opposition Labour Party might try to use ancient procedures to attempt to prevent the UK from leaving the EU without a deal if MPs vote down her Brexit compromise in the Autumn; ministers have said that May’s office has instructed them to highlight the possibility that if partliament rejected the Chequers deal, Labour could try and orchestrate a vote to stop Brexit happening at all, the FT reported.

* EUR: The single currencies were generally higher (though CHF found strength). ING expects the EUR to consolidate sideways after last week’s snoozefest ECB meeting, though suggests that Tuesday’s CPI and GDP might be a driver, but warns with core CPI still around 1%, there is no rush for markets to begin pricing in a hawkish stance from the ECB just yet. But if German inflation data, which came in line with expectations on Monday, is any guide, traders shouldn’t hold their breath. Technicians eye the 1.1690 level, which the EUR will need to close above to snap a fourth straight monthly loss. 

* JPY: Ahead of the BOJ’s policy meeting, the yen treads water within a narrow trading range. The general playbook seems to be expecting yen strength in the event that the BOJ goes ahead with policy tweaks, and yen weakness if the BOJ refrains from policy tweaks (but cuts its inflation view) and delivers a dovish disappointment. 

* COMMODITY FX: the complex is stronger, with AUD, NZD, CAD, NOK and RUB likely all tracking crude prices higher. With that said, AUD was subdued and struggling to meaningful rise above 0.74 vs the USD, as the AUDNZD cross slips back from around 1.0900 to sub-1.0850, and with the AUD still eyeing Yuan moves following another 6.8000+ mid-point PBOC fixing.

* EMFX: Most EMFX took advantage of USD weakness, though the TRY did not, with some suggesting that Monday’s weakness was a continuation of concerns about how it will conduct monetary policy going forward (more political interference, with a bias against lifting rates despite inflationary pressures). Ahead of its central bank decision this week, the BRL was also softer against the buck.  

* COMING-UP – BOJ POLICY ANNOUNCEMENT: BoJ will discuss potential changes to YCC, and ETF buys, sources have reported. Reports also suggest the central bank may cut its inflation forecasts. Decision due after Tokyo lunch break at 0330BST/2130CDT/1030HKT on 31 July 2018. Click here for full preview.

* COMING-UP – FOMC RATE DECISION: The FOMC will likely hold the fed funds rate target between 1.75-2.00%, no economic projections or post-meeting press conference with Chair Powell will leave focus on the statement. There are risks that the FOMC could issue a statement on the Fed’s independence, following the recent critique of high rates by US President Trump, which might be interpreted in a hawkish manner. Rate decision and statement to be published at 1400 EST/1900 BST on 1 August 2018. Click here to read full preview.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Dollar sold for month end and more
content:
DXY

Another bank portfolio model is flashing ‘sell Usd’, and an especially strong rebalancing vs the EUR, GBP and AUD for month end, but the Greenback and index are also sagging for other reasons. Last Friday’s US Q2 GDP data is still undermining the Dollar as the DXY slips back below 94.400, while positioning for the big trio of Central Bank meetings this week reflects market expectations for the BoJ and BoE to converge towards the Fed in terms of policy normalisation (to varying degrees). Hence, the JPY is also perky vs the Usd, and perhaps coincidentally centring on the 111.00 handle within a tight range around the big figure where 1 bn option expiries run off. Beyond that it’s down to the BoJ and whether it does tweak policy on yield curve control and ETF buying to allow more flexibility and ultimately less accommodation, with option break-evens suggesting an 80 pip +/- move on the risk event.

Back to the Pound, ‘super Thursday’ will be pivotal as Cable sits relatively firmly above 1.3100, but capped ahead of 1.3150-75 resistance and Eur/Gbp pivots 0.8900, and aside from the anticipated ¼ point rate hike there are several potential market-moving elements via the vote split, tone of the minutes and QIR plus Governor Carney’s presser.

NZD/EUR/CAD/CHF

Notwithstanding all the above, the Kiwi remains neck-and-neck with the single currency and SEK (on the back of significantly stronger than expected Swedish Q2 growth) at the top of the G10 pile, with firmer recovery gains above 0.6800. Eur/Usd is back on the 1.1700 (just) and the Loonie has almost touched 1.3000 with the added fuel of strong crude prices (WTI over $70/brl and Brent above $75/brl). The Franc is testing 0.9900 to the downside, and back to the Krona it is also bid vs the Usd, but off best levels vs the Eur around 10.2500 vs 10.2300 at one stage.

AUD

Relatively subdued and struggling to clear 0.7400 vs its US counterpart, as the Aud/Nzd cross slips back from around 1.0900 towards 1.0850, and with the Aussie Dollar still eyeing Yuan moves following another 6.8000+ mid-point PBoC fixing.   

Note, previews of the aforementioned Central Bank policy meetings are available on the Ransquawk Research Suite.

The 10 year benchmarks are at 161.59 vs 161.52 and 122.68 vs 122.60, with little in the way of technical props until 161.26 and 122.55, and the former also seeing some pressure from spread action vs BTPs (post-auction hedge unwind?). Meanwhile, the DXY also trades on a weaker footing post-last Friday’s somewhat underwhelming US Q2 GDP data and ahead of pending home sales, but more importantly the BoJ, FOMC and BoE that are widely expected to see a degree of the Fed’s relative hawkish premium pared back.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 30th July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European bourses mostly lower ahead of this week’s key risk events
  • Fixed Income losses have accelerated pretty sharply with big figure breaks triggering some stops
  • Looking ahead, highlights include national German CPI (following mixed state CPIs)

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week lacklustre after the tech-led declines last Friday on Wall Street and amid cautiousness ahead of this week's slew of risk events, while further CNH weakness also dampened sentiment. ASX 200 (-0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) were in the red with the worst performing stocks pressured by corporate updates including Syrah Resources and Dainippon Sumitomo Pharma. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were initially choppy after the PBoC refrained from reverse repo operations for a 7th consecutive occasion but noted that month-end fiscal spending will increase bank liquidity, while further CNH weakness eventually weighed on sentiment and proved to be the deciding factor. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally lower in a continuation of the losses triggered by ongoing BoJ speculation ahead of tomorrow’s policy announcement, while T-notes were uneventful amid tentativeness ahead of the looming risk events. Heading into EU trade, the BoJ once again announced a fixed-rate JGB operation which was met with a muted reaction by the market.

PBoC skipped repo operations for a CNY 130bln net drain and said month-end fiscal spending will raise bank liquidity. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8131 (Prev. 6.7942)

Chinese Commerce Ministry drafts revised rules in regards to foreign strategic investment in Chinese listed companies. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

UK government has reportedly agreed to give ECJ final say in arbitration regarding Brexit, divorce bill and potential Irish backstop in an effort to break the negotiation stalemate. (The Times)

UK PM May spokesman says technical notices during in August and September will set out sensible precautions in the event of a no-deal Brexit, this would also have consequences for the EU. (Newswires)

According to an investigation, a right-wing UK thinktank has offered ministerial access to potential US donors as it attempts to raise cash for research to support free-trade deals demanded by hardline Brexiteers. (The Guardian)

US President Trump threatened he would be willing to allow a government shutdown if the Democrats do not provide the votes for border security which includes building the wall. (Twitter).

U.S. Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he believes the quickening pace of growth in the US economy in Q2 will persist for the next 4-5 years. (Newswires)

US NEC Director Kudlow stated that trade discussions with EU regarding energy and agriculture will begin immediately. (Newswires)

Canada, EU, Japan, Mexico and South Korea are reportedly to meet in Geneva on Tuesday to discuss response to US tariff threats on auto imports. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President reportedly wants to set up an alliance with 6 Arab Gulf states to align against Iran. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European equity bourses are largely lower, with the FTSE MIB (+0.2%) the only bourse in the green, breaking through its 50 DMA of 21,913. Equity specific news is supporting the FTSE MIB and IBEX with Mediaset (+3.0%) reporting positive earnings. The AEX (-0.4%) is currently the underperforming bourse as index heavy-weights Heineken (-4.1%) and Altice (-2.4%) are both in the red on the back of negatively revised guidance and a branch sale.

Taking a look at sectors, broad based losses are being seen with slight underperformance noted in the IT sector, following on from uninspiring performance in US counterparts on Friday.

GVC Holdings (+4.8%) has assured a USD 200mln tie-up with the MGM group.

Traders now look ahead to after-market earnings, with French energy provider EDF and Pharma group Sanofi set to report Q2 figures. In terms of US earnings, Dow Jones heavyweight Caterpillar is to report at 07:30EDT.

FX

NOK/SEK - Ahead this week’s main events (BoJ, Fed, BoE and NFP), Scandi data has sprung some surprises and sparked marked divergence between the Crowns, with Norwegian retail sales down sharply in June (and more than reversing the previous month’s gain even after an upward revision) in stark contrast to stellar Q2 Swedish GDP in both q/q and y/y terms. In response, Eur/Nok mostly firmer within a 9.5535-5320 range vs Eur/Sek down from around 10.3100 to just over 10.2300 and the cross declining to circa 1.0735. Note, however, a US bank has shorted Eur/Nok above 9.5400 and is looking for a pronounced fall/reversal to 9.4200.

GBP/JPY - Cable is back above 1.3100 and Eur/Gbp hovering around 0.8900 ahead of a widely expected BoE rate hike this Thursday, but with the Pound not really reacting to firmer than forecast UK data (on balance) in the form of BoE consumer credit, mortgage approvals and lending, Chart-wise, 1.3150-75 represents near term resistance, while at least one major house believes a 25 bp tightening move is already priced in and has now gone short for a 1.2810 profit target. Conversely, amidst ongoing speculation about hawkish BoJ policy tweaks, Usd/Jpy is pivoting 111.00 and another US bank is eyeing a short position if the headline hits 111.40 for 104.00. Note, a decent 1 bn expiry runs off at 111.00 today and 111.27 forms technical resistance.

EUR/NZD - The next best G10 performers, after the Sek, with the single currency at the upper end of a 1.1650-90 range vs the Dollar after German state CPI indicating a modest upside bias for the national reading vs 2.1% y/y consensus. Meanwhile, a still very short Kiwi market is re-positioning again as weekly CFTC data shows the bearish base close to record levels and the likes of the BNZ see potential for a squeeze. Nzd/Usd back on the 0.6800 handle in response.

CHF/CAD/AUD - All narrowly mixed and close to recent ranges vs the Greenback, with the Franc at the low end of 0.9920-55 parameters, Loonie meandering between 1.3050-80 and Aud attempting to recover 0.7400.

EM - The Yuan and Lira have picked up where they left off last week, on the back foot, with Usd/Cny, Usd/Cnh and Usd/Try all higher. The PBoC set the on-shore fix at 6.8121, while the Lira continues to suffer after last week’s shock CBRT decision to leave key rates unchanged, with the focus now switching to the latest Inflation Report on Tuesday.

FIXED INCOME

The reversal from early intraday highs has continued and losses have accelerated pretty sharply with big figure breaks triggering some stops and then more pronounced declines once previous mtd lows were tested or even breached. The rationale, a broad return to bear-steepening, caution ahead of BoJ and BoE policy meetings and concerns about US funding and the yield curve, along with technical that have obviously turned more negative. Looking at Eurex and Liffe in more detail, Bunds are down to 161.52, -55 ticks, Gilts at 122.66, -48 ticks and US Treasuries also at fresh troughs for the overnight session with the long bond circa ½ point adrift.

COMMODITIES

WTI (+1.1%) and Brent Crude (+0.2%) have recuperated losses (with the latter retesting USD 74.50/bbl to the upside) seen at the back end of last week following an uptick in the Baker Hughes rig count while Mexican President Obrador stated his administration will hike crude production by 600K BPD. Though news flow remains relatively light, a 12-hour strike is to start at Total’s UK offshore platforms at 12:00BST.

Metals trade mostly lower with spot gold marginally easing, yet still rangebound, moving with an uneventful greenback ahead of key risk events this week (FOMC interest rate decision on Wednesday, US jobs data on Friday). Copper continues to trade lower while reports stated that workers at the world’s largest copper mine, Escondida mine in Chile, have rejected the final contract offer over wages and are voting whether to go on strike.

subject: UK PM May spokesman says technical notices during in August and September will set out sensible precautions in the event of a no-deal Brexit, this would also have consequences for the EU
analysis_details: • During the weekend, The Telegraph reported that UK PM May is being accused of a kamikaze-style approach to a no-deal Brexit by Brexiteers who state the government have only highlighted the negative impact to the UK from a no-deal in its reports, while they had hoped for the government’s preparations to include the negative impact a no-deal would have on the EU which may have provided the UK more leverage in negotiations.

All narrowly mixed and close to recent ranges vs the Greenback, with the Franc at the low end of 0.9930-55 parameters, Loonie meandering between 1.3055-80 and Aud attempting to recover 0.7400.

EM

Looking at Eurex and Liffe in more detail, Bunds are down to 161.54, -53 ticks, Gilts at 122.72, -42 ticks and US Treasuries also at fresh troughs for the overnight session with the long bond circa ½ point adrift.

COMMODITIES

WTI (+0.9%) and Brent Crude (+0.2%) recuperate losses (with the latter breaching USD 74.50/bbl to the upside) seen at the back end of last week following an uptick in the Baker Hughes rig count while Mexican President Obrador stated his administration will hike crude production by 600K BPD. Though news flow remains relatively light, a 12-hour strike is to start at Total’s UK offshore platforms at 12:00BST.

Metals trade mostly lower with spot gold marginally easing, yet still rangebound, moving with an uneventful greenback ahead of key risk events this week (FOMC interest rate decision on Wednesday, US jobs data on Friday). Gilts and Short Sterling: early upturn quickly faded
content: Gilts gapped up 15 ticks on their return to Liffe, in keeping with the early upside in Bunds, but the core UK bond immediately hit offers and topped out also in sympathy with fading German debt to trade down at 123.05 and 9 ticks below last Friday’s close. CPI data from Saxony showed an uptick in the y/y rate and this may have tempered the rise in Bunds, while UK fixed and STIRs are anticipating a BoE hike this week so clearly conscious of getting too carried away. Indeed, the 3 month strip has slipped back below parity having been a tick ahead earlier, and with attention turning towards Monday’s domestic agenda that encompasses BoE consumer credit, mortgage lending, approvals and money supply.

Bunds: slow grind higher ahead of German inflation data
content: The 10 year German debt future has overcome an early wobble and retreat from its initial 162.13 print to trade flat, climbing to a 162.30 peak stealthily ahead of the EU cash bourse opens and the first state CPI release from Saxony. Bunds have shrugged off weaker leads via JGBs ahead of the BoJ and flat US Treasuries with some support coming from within the Eurozone as Italian BTPs concede ground ahead of auctions. However, the German benchmark remains in a lower range having hit fresh July lows last week and subsequently fading on upticks ahead of 162.50.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

30th July 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week lacklustre after the tech-led declines last Friday on Wall Street and amid cautiousness ahead of this week's slew of risk events, while further CNH weakness also dampened sentiment. ASX 200 (-0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) were in the red with the worst performing stocks pressured by corporate updates including Syrah Resources and Dainippon Sumitomo Pharma. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were initially choppy after the PBoC refrained from reverse repo operations for a 7th consecutive occasion but noted that month-end fiscal spending will increase bank liquidity, while further CNH weakness eventually weighed on sentiment and proved to be the deciding factor. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally lower in a continuation of the losses triggered by ongoing BoJ speculation ahead of tomorrow’s policy announcement, while T-notes were uneventful amid tentativeness ahead of the looming risk events. Heading into EU trade, the BoJ once again announced a fixed-rate JGB operation which was met with a muted reaction by the market.

FTSE

UK firms - Banks are considering extending credit to firms in the event of a no-deal Brexit. (Telegraph)

BT (BT/A LN) – Co. is understood to have lost rights to broadcast NBA basketball and UFC ultimate fighting after walking away from a bidding contest. (BBC)

BHP Billiton (BLT LN) – Workers at the Escondida mine in Chile have rejected the final contract offer and have agreed to vote on whether to go on strike. (Newswires)

Indivior (INDV LN) – The co. has got FDA approval for PERSERIS for extended-release injectable suspension for treatment of schizophrenia in adults. (Newswires)

Standard Chartered (STAN LN) – The co. has agreed to further extension of the deferred US prosecution agreements until the year end. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Thomas Cook Group (TCG LN) – Industry sources have stated the company is rumoured to have held talks to sell its airline stake. (Times)

GVC Holdings (GVC LN) – The co. is reportedly set to assure a USD 200mln tie-up with the MGM group. (Guardian)

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – There co. has moved almost half of its Euro clearing activities to Frankfurt from London. (FT)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

* FUTURES: After the US cash equity open the ES -- which was going sideways overnight -- saw selling action. A combination of reasons was being thrown around: the FAANG weakness (add Twitter to that mix) this week was said to weigh on investor confidence, the VIX rose towards highs of the week, while haven currencies (JPY) were bid, while oil was sliding (Oil drillers add rigs for the first week in three, Baker Hughes said). Some also suggest that, ahead of next week's central bank activity (BOJ, FOMC, BOE), investors were taking chips off the table.

content:

  • Asian equity markets began the week lacklustre after the tech-led declines last Friday on Wall Street and ahead of this week's slew of risk events
  • The UK government has reportedly agreed to give ECJ final say in arbitration regarding Brexit, divorce bill and potential Irish backstop in an effort to break the negotiation stalemate
  • Looking ahead, highlights include regional and national German CPIs

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week lacklustre after the tech-led declines last Friday on Wall Street and amid cautiousness ahead of this week's slew of risk events, while further CNH weakness also dampened sentiment. ASX 200 (-0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) were in the red with the worst performing stocks pressured by corporate updates including Syrah Resources and Dainippon Sumitomo Pharma. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were initially choppy after the PBoC refrained from reverse repo operations for a 7th consecutive occasion but noted that month-end fiscal spending will increase bank liquidity, while further CNH weakness eventually weighed on sentiment and proved to be the deciding factor. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally lower in a continuation of the losses triggered by ongoing BoJ speculation ahead of tomorrow’s policy announcement, while T-notes were uneventful amid tentativeness ahead of the looming risk events. Heading into EU trade, the BoJ once again announced a fixed-rate JGB operation which was met with a muted reaction by the market.

PBoC skipped repo operations for a CNY 130bln net drain and said month-end fiscal spending will raise bank liquidity. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8131 (Prev. 6.7942)
 

UK/EU

UK government has reportedly agreed to give ECJ final say in arbitration regarding Brexit, divorce bill and potential Irish backstop in an effort to break the negotiation stalemate. (The Times)

UK PM May is being accused of a kamikaze-style approach to a no-deal Brexit by Brexiteers who state the government have only highlighted the negative impact to the UK from a no-deal in its reports, while they had hoped for the government’s preparations to include the negative impact a no-deal would have on the EU which may have provided the UK more leverage in negotiations. (Telegraph)

Italy reportedly provided some hope for UK PM May after Italian Deputy PM Salvini stated the government would support the UK in trade discussions and accused the EU of attempting to swindle UK Brexit voters. In other news, there were also comments from Italian Deputy PM Di Maio that a referendum on whether Italy should leave the Euro is not in governing contract and will not be pursued. (Newswires)

A group of international experts is working on a plan for a potential free trade agreement between Britain and United States that could pave the way for a new, seamless trading bloc to rival the EU. (Times)

UK Foreign Secretary Hunt is to visit China to revitalise Anglo-Chinese relations. (The Guardian)

According to an investigation, a right-wing UK thinktank has offered ministerial access to potential US donors as it attempts to raise cash for research to support free-trade deals demanded by hardline Brexiteers. (The Guardian)


FX

Price action across the major FX pairs was quiet due to a lack of data releases and amid a tentative tone ahead of an abundance of central bank activity including policy decisions from the BoJ, Fed, BoE and RBI, while the latest NFP data on Friday will top off this week’s storm of risk events. As such, the greenback was flat which kept price action in EUR/USD and GBP/USD restricted with the latter just about holding onto the 1.3100 handle. Elsewhere, JPY was indecisive amid the varied speculation regarding potential policy tweaks by the BoJ, while antipodeans were lacklustre with brief pressure seen as CNH dropped another 500 pips against the greenback after the PBoC resumed its weakening of the reference rate.
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were subdued overnight amid the cautious tone with WTI crude futures contained below USD 69.00/bbl following Friday’s losses amid reports Mexico plans to raise oil output and after US Defence Secretary Mattis dismissed rumours the US was prepared to strike Iranian nuclear capabilities. Elsewhere, gold was kept rangebound by an uneventful greenback and hesitation ahead of the upcoming risk events, while copper was lacklustre alongside a broad risk averse tone.

Mexican President Lopez Obrador said on Friday that his administration will boost crude production to 2.5mln BPD from current 1.9mln BPD. (Newswires)

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (27 Jul) 1048 (Prev. 1046). (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US President reportedly wants to set up an alliance with 6 Arab Gulf states to align against Iran. (Newswires)


US

The complex was higher, with the curve garnering some support as the tech slide continued, though volume was thin, and yields only came in modestly; at one point, however, three-year yields found fresh highs not seen in over a decade. There was choppy trade around the GDP release (bias to the upside), but ultimately, there was not a lot to sing home about. Attention on next week’s quarterly refunding and FOMC, and, given its impact on Treasuries recently, the BOJ meeting at the early part of the week. US 10YR T-notes futures (U8) settled 3 ticks higher at 119-14.

US President Trump threatened he would be willing to allow a government shutdown if the Democrats do not provide the votes for border security which includes building the wall. (Twitter).

U.S. Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he believes the quickening pace of growth in the US economy in Q2 will persist for the next 4-5 years. (Newswires)

OMB Director Mulvaney said President Trump respects the Fed's independence, while he added that 4% growth is manageable and that he has confidence growth is sustainable. (Newswires)

US NEC Director Kudlow stated that trade discussions with EU regarding energy and agriculture will begin immediately. (Newswires)

Canada, EU, Japan, Mexico and South Korea are reportedly to meet in Geneva on Tuesday to discuss response to US tariff threats on auto imports. (Newswires)
